title: Leaky Oculus Skylight Expected to Cost $200,000 More to Fix
text:
Officials are scrambling to waterproof the leaky skylight at the World Trade Center Oculus as the $3.9 billion transit hub prepares to face another New York winter.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has spent at least $50,000 sealing the retractable skylight with water-resistant tape after it sprung a leak in 2018, according to a person familiar with the skylight’s operation.

A spokesman for the public agency declined to confirm or deny that figure. But he said that the agency expects to spend a further $200,000 sealing the skylight with a waterproof membrane. That work is under way.

The skylight is made up of dozens of glass panels that run for 355 feet along the soaring building’s spine. It is powered by a complex mechanical system with 120 motors, which must move in sync when the skylight opens and closes.

A worker Thursday on the skylight at the Oculus, which is made up of dozens of glass panels that run for 355 feet along the soaring building’s spine. Photo: Sarah Blesener for The Wall Street Journal

The skylight is supposed to open on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Officials believe that the system malfunctioned during such an opening on Sept. 11, 2018, ripping a rubber seal that runs along the length of the roof.

That rip led to a series of leaks in which water dripped onto the white marble concourse, where tourists and shoppers mingle with commuters streaming between stations on the New York City subway and the PATH rail system.

In May, officials said they hoped to fix the skylight in time for this year’s Sept. 11 anniversary. But the skylight remained closed this year for the first time since the building opened in 2016.

The architect who designed the Oculus, Santiago Calatrava, initially proposed that the entire roof pivot open. But as costs for the building soared past their $2 billion budget, Port Authority officials scaled back the design to a skylight, which cost $32 million.

The Port Authority spokesman said Thursday that the agency is conducting an engineering analysis with a view to repairing the skylight. “While that analysis is on-going, we are taking prudent steps to better protect the skylight with a more durable barrier system,” he said.

The Oculus was built in the aftermath of the terror attacks on the World Trade Center. It is positioned at an angle so that the skylight captures the sun each year during the hours when the planes struck the twin towers and the buildings collapsed.
description: Officials are scrambling to waterproof the leaky skylight at the World Trade Center Oculus transit hub before winter, with additional outlays of $200,000 expected.
